fields.headline: Palindromes
fields.bodyText: Since his tragicomic masterwork Happiness, there has been a falling-off in the impact that Todd Solondz has had with his films, but here he enforces his reputation as the Diane Arbus of modern American cinema. Solondz unerringly finds the grotesque, the marginalised and the dispossessed. Are they simply a freak show? Do we laugh at them, with them, or not laugh at all? Or has Solondz found a way out of the traditional constraints of restraint, respect and correctness, smashing through into a new realm of post-modern empathy? Palindromes is about a 12-year-old girl called Aviva (incurious when someone points out that her name is the same forward and backward), who runs away from home with one goal in view - to get pregnant. A Buñuelian alienation technique neutralises any possible sympathy or anxiety we might feel for Aviva. She is played by half a dozen different actresses, ranging from a tiny white waif to a very big African-American woman. It keeps the viewer on edge and off balance, and certainly constitutes a startling formal challenge thrown down to the audience.
